title: Contributing to bbousuite
text: want make bigger change, ’s good idea first file issue make sure someone team agrees ’s needed. ’ve found bug, please file issue illustrates bug minimal reprex (also help write unit test, needed).

title: Contributing to bbousuite
text: Fork package clone onto computer. haven’t done , recommend using usethis::create_from_github("", fork = TRUE). Install development dependences devtools::install_dev_deps(), make sure package passes R CMD check running devtools::check(). R CMD check doesn’t pass cleanly, ’s good idea ask help continuing. Create Git branch pull request (PR). recommend using usethis::pr_init("brief-description--change"). Make changes, commit git, create PR running usethis::pr_push(), following prompts browser. title PR briefly describe change. body PR contain Fixes #issue-number. Begin commit merge messages - indicate user facing changes included NEWS.md. use fledge automatically generate NEWS.md file.

title: Contributing to bbousuite
text: New code follow tidyverse style guide. can use styler package apply styles, please don’t restyle code nothing PR. use roxygen2, Markdown syntax, documentation. use testthat unit tests. Contributions test cases included easier accept.

title: Contributing to bbousuite

title: Getting help with bbousuite
text: opening new issue, sure search issues pull requests make sure bug hasn’t reported /already fixed development version. default, search pre-populated :issue :open. can edit qualifiers (e.g. :pr, :closed) needed. example, ’d simply remove :open search issues repo, open closed.

title: Getting help with bbousuite
text: Start making minimal reproducible example using reprex package. haven’t heard used reprex , ’re treat! Seriously, reprex make R-question-asking endeavors easier (pretty insane ROI five ten minutes ’ll take learn ’s ). additional reprex pointers, check Get help! section tidyverse site.

title: Empirical comparison of traditional and Bayesian approaches to estimate survival, recruitment and trend
text: overall objective empirical comparisons explore working characteristics Bayesian Hatter-Bergerud method estimation trend. methodology evolution traditional simulation-based approach therefore practitioners interested Bayesian methods perform relative traditional methods. key objective understanding Bayesian approaches may offset low sample sizes observations (collared caribou groups observed composition surveys) typical caribou data sets. note empirical comparisons limited true parameter values known. Therefore, can conclude whether estimates similar different approaches rather infer bias. fully explore estimators also present simulations allow assessment bias working characteristics across full range scenarios.

what: Differences and similarities in traditional and Bayesian approaches
title: Empirical comparison of traditional and Bayesian approaches to estimate survival, recruitment and trend
text: key difference traditional, fixed effect, random effects methods yearly monthly estimates treated. categorical variable, year month treated fixed effect parameter value estimated isolation. Traditional methods treat variables fixed effects. contrast, variables treated random effect parameter values assumed drawn common underlying distribution allows typical values estimated parameter estimate influenced ones. difference traditional Bayesian approaches whether data assumed come pre-defined statistical distribution. Traditional approaches non-parametric meaning assume data comes statistical distribution estimates based simple ratios. Variances estimated using approximation formulas (survival) bootstrap resampling methods. Bayesian fixed random effects model survival recruitment use parametric approach survival recruitment modeled using binomial distribution. main advantage Bayesian fixed random effects models inference based underlying statistical model allowing inference statistical significance model parameters. example, models assume underlying trend demographic parameters can applied using parametric approach. addition, estimates standard error can derived years 0 mortalities using fixed effects models comparison traditional approaches confidence interval possible.

title: Empirical comparison of traditional and Bayesian approaches to estimate survival, recruitment and trend
text: Traditional Bayesian methods use staggered entry Kaplan-Meier method, defined algebraically (Pollock et al. 1989). probability surviving ith time step (usually month) given equation \hat{S}_{} = 1 - \frac{d_{}}{r_{}} d_{} number mortalities period r_{} number collared individuals start period. estimated survival arbitrary time period t (usually year) given \hat{S}(t) = \prod_{=1}(\hat{S}_{,t}) S survival ith time step tth period. Traditional approaches use simple product monthly survival estimates obtain yearly survival estimates. Bayesian approaches model survival based binomial distribution. Fixed effects Bayesian models treat monthly survival random effect yearly survival fixed effect meaning parameter estimated every year. details Kaplan-Meier approach applied boreal caribou studies given vignette("previous-methods").

previous_headings: Methods and results > Review of formulas used to estimate survival, recruitment, and trend.
title: Empirical comparison of traditional and Bayesian approaches to estimate survival, recruitment and trend
text: traditional Bayesian approaches estimate recruitment following methods DeCesare et al. (2012). age ratio, X, commonly estimated number calves, n{_j}, per adult female, n_{af}, observed end measured year, X = \frac{n_j}{n_{af}} X \cdot sex\_ratio estimates number female calves (n_{jf}) per adult female. Recruitment estimated using equation accounts recruitment calves yearling/adult age class end caribou year. R_{RM} = \frac{X \cdot sex\_ratio}{1 + X \cdot sex\_ratio} traditional methods, estimates based upon raw ratios field data whereas recruitment modelled based binomial distribution Bayesian methods.

text: traditional Bayesian approaches use basic Hatter-Bergerud method (Hatter Bergerud 1991). basic Hatter-Bergerud equation used estimate \lambda given . \lambda = \frac{(S)}{(1 - R)} Variance lambda estimates estimated using simulation approach traditional approach whereas variances estimates using Markov Monte Carlo methods Bayesian approaches. resulting estimates variances influenced individual assumptions made estimation survival recruitment.

title: Empirical comparison of traditional and Bayesian approaches to estimate survival, recruitment and trend
text: use 32 year field data set (data set “” bboudata) compare methodologies. data use bbouretro estimate traditional bboutools estimate fixed random effects survival, recruitment, trend. comparison estimates reveals similarity fixed effect traditional estimates (Figure 1). result intuitive given approaches treating years independent data sets given underlying formulae 2 approaches similar. main difference random effects traditional/fixed effect estimates. case can seen distribution random effect estimates truncated lower estimates random effects models higher traditional/random effects vice versa higher estimates. due “shrinkage” estimates. Namely, sharing information across years random effects estimates causes outlier estimates brought towards mean random effect value. particularly case underlying data estimates sparse. example, lowest estimate survival (0.6) based mean sample size 7.2 collars monitored per year. Fig. 1: Comparison traditional Bayesian estimates survival, recruitment λ. yearly plot reveals similar trends random effects estimates showing least variation compared traditional fixed effects estimates (Figure 2). notable difference 1990 1991 collar sample sizes lower (<10 collars monitored per month) creating estimates survival near 1 traditional fixed effects estimates. However, methods follow general temporal trends estimates. Fig. 2: Comparison traditional Bayesian estimates survival, recruitment λ year. additional interest relative precision estimates indicated width confidence interval divided estimate. comparison traditional Bayesian fixed random effects reveals higher estimated precision random effect estimators whereas estimated precision fixed effect traditional approaches relatively similar (Figure 3). Fig. 3: Relative estimated precision traditional, random fixed effects methods. Precision indexed width confidence limit divided estimate. One main factors influencing estimate precision sample size data set used obtain estimates. influence sample size explored survival rate estimates plotting mean number collars monitored comparison point estimates relative precision estimates indexed confidence interval width divided estimate. comparison reveals traditional Bayesian fixed effects influenced sample size terms point estimates (Figure 4) estimated precision (Figure 5) compared random effects models. sample sizes larger range survival rates result including unrealistically low high estimates traditional fixed effects models. Fig. 4: Comparison effect mean collars monitored point estimates survival traditional Bayesian random fixed effect estimators. Relative precision estimates also influenced sample size collars traditional fixed effects methods (Figure 5). Differences estimated precision fixed effects traditional models partially caused fixed effects models estimating confidence limit survival estimates 1 (deaths).  Fig. 5: Comparison effect mean collars monitored point estimates survival traditional Bayesian random fixed effect estimators. main reason differences estimates traditional fixed effects approaches consider yearly data set independently whereas random effects models consider entire multi-year data set (drawn distribution survival values). result, estimates stable random effects models.

title: Empirical comparison of traditional and Bayesian approaches to estimate survival, recruitment and trend
text: Empirical comparisons illustrate potential advantages using random effects methods estimate survival, recruitment, trend. Namely, sharing information across years random effects models potentially offsets issues sparse data creating unrealistic estimates traditional fixed effect approaches. main question whether cases random effects may create bias dismissing low high parameter estimates actually occurring. explore question well overall performance estimators use simulations. Unlike empirical comparisons, simulations allow assessment performance known true parameter values therefore allowing assessment overall estimate performance.

title: Boreal Caribou Simulations Analysis
text: objectives analysis : Simulate Boreal Caribou recruitment survival data key demographic sampling parameters. Assess ability various statistical methods recover known parameter values simulated data. One hundred recruitment survival data sets simulated single set demographic (table 1) sampling (table 2) parameters 5 coverage scenarios (table 3). Coverage scenarios included variation number collared adult females (survival data) proportion groups observed hypothetical composition surveys (recruitment data). Realistic parameter values survival/fecundity rates population simulation derived observed values anonymized example datasets. simulated population stable (.e., lambda close 1; table 4). See bbousims vignette information survival recruitment data simulated, given parameter values table 1 table 2. Statistical methods compared include Bayesian model year fixed effect, Bayesian model year random effect, frequentist retro model. See bboutools vignette details statistical methods. Bayesian models uninformative priors. Performance metrics used include bias, precision coverage. Bias measure degree estimate - -estimates true value. unbiased estimator one mean bias across estimates zero. Precision simply difference upper lower limits 95% CI. Note Bayesian models CI refers credible interval, whereas CI represents confidence interval frequentist methods. Coverage proportion estimates 95% CI contain true value. performance metrics visualized boxplots, display median 95% interquartile range. boxplot summary 2000 points (.e., 100 simulations 20 years). Frequentist retro methods fail estimate standard error (95% CI) annual survival 0 observed mortalities. cases, annual population growth (lambda) estimates also missing 95% CI. important note precision plots exclude values coverage plots assume known value within 95% CI. number (proportion) cases summarized coverage scenario table 5 6.

title: Boreal Caribou Simulations Analysis
text: survival model, higher sample size resulted reduced bias, higher precision higher coverage statistical methods. Bayesian random effects model performed best, improvement methods particularly lower sample sizes. Results recruitment model less clear, methods performing similarly across sample sizes. Surprisingly, coverage reduced higher proportion groups observed Bayesian recruitment models. suspect caused higher precision leading higher tendency 95% CI include true value. Considering population growth estimates generally, Bayesian random effects model performed best. growth predictions derived recruitment survival estimates thus, unsurprising Bayesian random effects model performed best. consequence modeling year random effect individual estimates pulled toward grand mean, especially estimates low precision extreme (Kery Schaub 2011). simulation analysis demonstrates ‘shrinkage’ desirable random effects model tends skeptical extreme values. Extreme values likely result sampling process rather ecological processes, especially low sample sizes.

what: Easily Install and Load `bbou` (Boreal cariBOU) Packages
title: Easily Install and Load `bbou` (Boreal cariBOU) Packages
text: goal bbousuite make easy install load (bbou) suite R packages Boreal cariBOU. bbousuite set R packages facilitate simulation analysis boreal caribou survival recruitment data estimate population growth. consists : bboudata, collection simulated anonymized empirical survival recruitment datasets. bboutools, set functions estimate population growth Bayesian Maximum Likelihood (ML) framework, implemented hood using Nimble R package. bboushiny, Graphical User Interface (GUI) bboutools. bbouretro, set functions estimate population growth using traditional frequentist methods. bbousims, set functions simulate survival recruitment data hypothetical radio-collaring composition surveys. R package website function documentation ‘Get Started’ guide. completely new bbou suite, recommend taking look bboutools ‘Get Started’ guide demonstrates core functionality methods. also several vignettes, including bboutools analytical methods prior selection, bbouretro analytical methods, using bbousims bboutools, comparison Bayesian traditional method estimates empirical simulated data.

what: bbousuite: Easily Install and Load `bbou` (Boreal cariBOU) Packages — bbousuite-package
title: bbousuite: Easily Install and Load `bbou` (Boreal cariBOU) Packages — bbousuite-package
text: `bbou` suite packages designed allow analysis (`bbouretro` `bboutools`) simulation (`bbousims`) Boreal Caribou survival recruitment data ('bboudata') estimate population growth rates. shiny app also available (`bboushiny`).
